title: Who is Kirillov in Dostojewskij's "The Possessed" and what is his thesis on the new man and the transformation of the world?
first_phrase: This text explores Kirillov's philosophy in "The Possessed" by F. Dostoyevsky. Kirillov believes that fear is what makes humans miserable and unhappy. He argues that there will be a new man who is happy and fearless, who will become like God and transform the world. The author emphasizes that Kirillov's ideas should not be taken literally but instead viewed as a metaphor for freeing oneself from fear. This discussion relates to the metaphysics of pain and initiation explored earlier in the chapter.

last_phrase: In conclusion, Kirillov's radical ideas of the annihilation of God and the physical transformation of man may seem sacrilegious, but they can still be interpreted as a metaphor for the liberation of the individual from fear and the embrace of a new, fearless way of life. The old God must be overcome for a new man to emerge, one who is happy, fearless, and unafraid of death.
